name: Collared Peccary
description: It has a slender, laterally compressed body and tall legs. Its coloration is gray-brown, with a white 'collar' around the neck.
spread_note: From the southern USA to the temperate zone of South America, except the northeastern part
food_note: Plants (fruits, tubers), less often small animals and carrion
proportions: Body length 80–100 cm; tail length 3–5 cm; shoulder height 30–50 cm; weight 15–30 kg
attractions: Peccaries replace the pig family in South and Central America. Unlike their relatives, their young aren’t striped but cinnamon-brown. They spend most of their time foraging, digging up soft forest soil with their flat snouts. Collared peccaries live in tight-knit social groups, recognizing each other mainly by scent. They have a scent gland on the back, which group members rub against each other.
breeding: Peccaries enriched Prague Zoo’s collection during wartime. One male lived here from 1942 to 1955, and since then, we’ve kept this species almost continuously. The first young, a male, was successfully raised in 1960, and over 200 have been born to date.
